tit.cmt: hatsuho 読みの通りとしました。

sen.j: 初穂（はつほ）とは、日本において秋のイネの収獲に先立って神 (神道)に献じる熟した稲穂のことである。
sen.e: In Japan, hatsuho rice ear is a ripe rice ear presented to God (Shinto) before autumn rice harvest.

sen.j: 早穂（はやほ）、先穂（さきほ）、最華（さいか）などとも言う。
sen.e: It is also called hayaho, sakiho, or saika.

sen.j: 古代においては、祭祀を主導した豪族がその費用や供物とするために支配民から徴収したものが初穂であったという。
sen.e: It is said that in ancient time, a local ruling family who spearheaded Saishi (religious service) collected hatsuho rice ear from subject people in order to cover the expenses or to use it as altarage.
It is said that in ancient times, a local ruling family who spearheaded Saishi (religious service) collected hatsuho rice ear from subjects in order to cover the expenses or to use it as altarage.

sen.j: 後に豪族の政治・宗教権限がヤマト王権に剥奪されて律令政府が確立されると、初穂は律令政府を代理する国府に納められる田租（でんそ・「租」）へと転換して、後の租庸調制を構成する1つとなったとされている。
sen.e: When Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) wrested the political and religious powers from local ruling families, and then established the ancient Japanese government of centralized governance, hatsuho changed the form into denso (rice field tax) which was paid to a kokufu (provincial office) representing the ancient Japanese government of centralized governance, and then the denso became a component of the Soyocho system.

sen.j: 今日、伊勢神宮では神嘗祭に先立って抜穂祭が行われている。
sen.e: Today, the Ise Jingu Shrine holds Nukiho-sai Festival before Kannamesai.

sen.j: その他の神社や一部地域の民間でも秋の収獲祭より以前（八朔、重陽など）に抜穂の行事を行う所がある。

sen.j: これが初穂の元来の形と考えられる。
sen.e: This is considered the original form of hatsuho.

sen.j: 元々は文字通り稲（を含む穀物）の穂であった。
sen.e: Originally, the literal meaning of hatsuho was rice ear.

sen.j: その年初めて獲れた野菜や海産物、狩の獲物を神仏に供えるものも初穂と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: Vegetables, seafoods or preys which are gained and presented to Shinto and Buddhist deities at the beginning of the year were also called hatsuho.

sen.j: このような、その年初めてのものを神に供えるという初穂の習慣が、後に、「初物」と呼んでそれを貴んだり、近隣や知人の間で初物を贈りあったりする習慣に発展した。
sen.e: Such a hatsuho tradition as first supply was presented to the gods, later came to be called 'primeur' and valued, and then was developed into a tradition of giving first supply to neighbors or acquaintances.

This hatsuho tradition, of supplying the gods first at the beginning of the year, later came to be called 'primeur' and valued, and was then developed into a tradition of giving the year's starting supply to neighbors or acquaintances.

This hatsuho tradition, of supplying gods with things harvested first (first fruit) of the year, later came to be called 'hatsumono' (primeur) and valued, and was then developed into a tradition of giving hatsumono to neighbors or acquaintances.
